facts: Their bright blue skin serves as a warning to predators that they are highly toxic.
In captivity, they lose their toxicity because it comes from the specific insects they eat in the wild.
Each frog has a unique pattern of black spots, similar to human fingerprints.
They have excellent eyesight, allowing them to spot tiny movements even in low light.
Indigenous people sometimes used their toxins for blowgun darts.
Their striking red eyes are used for 'startle coloration' to confuse predators while the frog escapes.
They are nocturnal, spending their days hidden on the underside of leaves.
They have suction-pad-like toes that emit a wet mucus for climbing.
They blink their large eyes to help push insects down their throats while eating.
Males shake their bodies to create vibrations, signaling their territory to others.
They are apex predators in ponds and have been known to eat snakes and small birds.
Adults can grow up to 8 inches long and weigh over a pound.
Their deep 'jug-o-rum' call can be heard from over a mile away.
Bullfrog tadpoles can take up to two years to transform into adult frogs.
They are the largest true frog species in North America.
They are often found near porch lights hunting for insects at night.
They are known for their distinctive bird-like barking call.
They can change their color slightly from bright green to dull brown to match their surroundings.
They have large, sticky toe pads that make them expert climbers.
They are incredibly adaptable and can be found almost anywhere in Europe with water.
During winter, they may hibernate at the bottom of ponds, breathing through their skin.
They have a distinctive dark patch or 'mask' behind their eyes.
They can breathe through both their lungs and their skin.
Males can be as big as a dinner plate and weight over 3 pounds.
Unlike most frogs, the male stays to guard its tadpoles against predators.
They have tooth-like projections on their lower jaw to help grip large prey.
They can survive for months underground in a cocoon of dead skin during dry seasons.

common_name: Green and Black Poison Dart Frog
facts: They are native to Central and South America and are known for their beautiful green patterns.
Males are dedicated fathers, carrying their tadpoles to water in bromeliads.
Their skin secretions were used by local tribes to poison arrows and darts.
They are most active during the day (diurnal) and hunt for small ants and mites.
They are often called 'Blue Jeans' frogs because of their red bodies and blue legs.
Mothers individually carry each tadpole on their backs to small water pools in plants.
The mother feeds her tadpoles unfertilized eggs until they transform into froglets.
They are found in the humid lowlands of Central America.
When threatened, they inflate their bodies to look like a giant, unswallowable tomato.
They can secrete a sticky, white glue-like substance that can numb a predator's mouth.
They are native exclusively to the island of Madagascar.
Females are much brighter and larger than the males.
Their underside skin is completely translucent, making their internal organs visible.
They can hide their red blood cells in their liver while sleeping to become even more transparent.
They are primarily nocturnal and live in trees near fast-flowing mountain streams.
Males aggressively guard their eggs against wasps and other predators.
They perfectly resemble a clump of moss, making them nearly invisible on wet rocks.
When frightened, they curl into a ball and 'play dead' to look like a mossy stone.
They can throw their voice, making their call sound like it's coming from far away.
They live in flooded caves and on the banks of mountain streams.
They are nicknamed 'Pacman' because of their voracious appetite and giant mouths.
They bury themselves in the leaf litter and wait for prey to walk blindly by.
They have a very powerful bite and will try to eat anything that fits in their mouth.
In the wild, they have been known to eat other frogs, rodents, and even small birds.
